and where the Court’s review would actually make a dif-
ference.
Certiorari should be denied.
STATEMENT
A. Statutory And Regulatory Background
1. 
The Telephone Consumer Protection Act
Subject to certain exceptions, the TCPA prohibits 
the “use [of] any [1] telephone facsimile machine, [2] com-
puter, or [3] other device to send, to a [1] telephone fac-
simile machine, an unsolicited advertisement.”  47 U.S.C. 
§ 227(b)(1)(C); see id. § 227(b)(1)(C)(i)-(iii) (exceptions).  
$´WHOHSKRQHIDFVLPLOHPDFKLQHµLVGHÀQHGDV´HTXLS-
ment which has the capacity (A) to transcribe text or 
images, or both, from paper into an electronic signal and 
to transmit that signal over a regular telephone line, or 
(B) to transcribe text or images (or both) from an elec-
tronic signal received over a regular telephone line onto 
paper.” Id. § 227(a)(3); see 47 C.F.R. § 64.1200(f)(14) (same). 
The TCPA creates a private right of action for a vio-
lation of Section 227(b) or its implementing regulations. 
Id. § 227(b)(3)(A).  Plaintiffs may seek actual damages or 
$500 in statutory damages “for each such violation.”  Id. 
§ 227(b)(3)(B).  

5
2. 
FCC authority and judicial review
Congress authorized the FCC to “prescribe regula-
tions to implement the requirements” of the TCPA.  Id. 
§ 227(b)(2).  Like other agencies, the FCC also has adju-
dicatory authority to “issue a declaratory order” to “ter-
minate a controversy or remove uncertainty” in the laws 
it administers.  5 U.S.C. § 554(e); see 47 C.F.R. § 1.2(a).
This case involves a declaratory order issued by an FCC 
component on delegated authority.  Congress expressly 
authorized the FCC to delegate “any of its functions” 
(subject to certain exceptions not relevant here) to its staff. 
47 U.S.C. § 155(c)(1).  Any person aggrieved by an action

FCC orders
a. 
Amerifactors

adjudicate whether “online fax services” are “telephone 
facsimile machines” within the meaning of the TCPA. 
Pet. App. 47a (“Amerifactors”).  “An online fax service is 
‘a cloud-based service consisting of a fax server or similar 
device that is used to send or receive documents, images 
DQGRUHOHFWURQLFÀOHVLQGLJLWDOIRUPDWRYHUWHOHFRPPXQL-
cations facilities’ that allows users to ‘access “faxes” the 
same way that they do email.’”  Ibid. (footnote omitted).
Acting on delegated authority, the FCC’s Consumer 
and Governmental Affairs Bureau decided the petition 
after notice and comment.  Pet. App. 49a, 56a (citing 
47 C.F.R. §§ 0.141, 0.361).  It issued a declaratory order 
stating that an online fax service “is not a ‘telephone 
facsimile machine’ and thus falls outside the scope of the 
statutory prohibition.”  Pet. App. 48a.  That conclusion 
followed from the statute’s text, its underlying purposes, 
and the large amount of information in the record “on 
the nature and operations of current online fax services.” 
Pet. App. 50a.
The Bureau’s analysis began with the statute’s text: 
“the TCPA’s language demonstrates that Congress did 
not intend the statute’s prohibition to apply to faxes sent 
to equipment other than a telephone facsimile machine.” 
Pet. App. 51a.  While “Congress made clear that the pro-

7
scription applies when such a fax is sent from other 
devices”—such as “a ‘computer,’ or any ‘other device’”—
“the language of the statute proscribes sending a fax only 
to a ‘telephone facsimile machine.’”  Pet. App. 51a-52a 
(quoting 47 U.S.C. § 227(b)(1)(C)) (emphases added).
The Bureau then explained that online fax services

facsimile machine.”  Pet. App. 52a.  A “fax received by an 
online fax service as an electronic message is effectively 
an email.”  Ibid.  And because “an online fax service can-
not itself print a fax,” “an online fax service is plainly not 
‘equipment which has the capacity * * * to transcribe text 
or images (or both) from an electronic signal received over 
a regular telephone line onto paper.’”  Pet. App. 52a-53a 
(quoting 47 U.S.C. § 227(a)(3)).  That straightforward 
understanding of the plain statutory language was consis-
tent with the FCC’s longstanding view “that the TCPA’s 
prohibition [on faxing unsolicited advertisements] does not 
extend to facsimile messages ‘sent as email over the Inter-
net.’”  Pet. App. 48a (citing Rules & Reguls. Implementing 
the Tel. Consumer Prot. Act of 1991, 18 FCC Rcd. 14014, 
14133 ¶200 (2003)).

AUGUST 5, 2024

QUESTION PRESENTED
In 2019, a Federal Communications Commission 
(FCC) bureau issued a declaratory order clarifying 
that online fax services, whose users essentially receive 
faxes as email attachments, are not “telephone facsimile 
machine[s]” under the Telephone Consumer Protection 
Act (TCPA).  It based its conclusion on, among other 
things, online fax services’ inability to “transcribe text 
* * * onto paper,” a statutory requirement for a “telephone 
facsimile machine.”  47 U.S.C. § 227(a)(3). 
In this private-party TCPA action, the court of 
appeals held in an unpublished memorandum decision 
that the district court correctly followed the FCC bureau’s 
determination on the scope of “telephone facsimile 
machine.”  That determination, the court of appeals 
explained, would ultimately be reviewable only under the 
Hobbs Act, 28 U.S.C. § 2342(1). 
The question presented is:
Whether the court of appeals correctly held that a 
TCPA plaintiff may not collaterally attack an FCC bureau’s 
declaratory order limiting the scope of defendant’s liability 
when that order will ultimately be subject to review under 
the Hobbs Act; and, regardless, whether the TCPA’s 
plain text, structure, and purpose show that online fax 
services are not “telephone facsimile machines” and thus 
not covered by the statute.

ii
CORPORATE DISCLOSURE STATEMENT
McKesson Corporation is a publicly traded company. 
McKesson Corporation has no parent corporation, and 
no publicly held corporation owns 10% or more of its 
stock.  McKesson Technologies, Inc., which became 
McKesson Technologies LLC in 2017, was a wholly owned 
subsidiary of McKesson Corporation.  In 2018, McKesson 
Technologies LLC was acquired by Change Healthcare. 
As part of the sale agreement, McKesson Corporation 
retained responsibility for McKesson Technologies LLC’s 
obligations related to this suit.  McKesson Corporation 
currently has no ownership or direct or indirect voting 
interest in either Change Healthcare or McKesson 
Technologies LLC.

INTRODUCTION
According to petitioner, “[t]his case presents an 
ideal vehicle to resolve the question presented, but left 
undecided,” in PDR Network, LLC v. Carlton & Harris 
Chiropractic, Inc., 588 U.S. 1 (2019).  Pet. 2.  In reality, 
the question presented here is different from that in PDR 
NetworkDQGWKHSHWLWLRQSUHVHQWVDÁDZHGYHKLFOHIRU
review.
In PDR Network, a defendant who had been sued 
under the Telephone Consumer Protection Act contended 
that its conduct was not covered by the statute.  Years 
before, the Federal Communications Commission had 
issued an order suggesting otherwise.  The question before 
this Court was whether the exclusive direct review scheme 
for FCC orders established by the Hobbs Act barred the 
defendant from defending itself by questioning the FCC 
order’s understanding of the statute.  PDR Network, 
588 U.S. at 3-4.
7KH&RXUW´IRXQGLWGLIÀFXOWWRDQVZHUWKLVTXHVWLRQ
for the answer may depend upon the resolution of two

Justices, Justice Kavanaugh would have applied the “tra-

tions under the Due Process Clause.”  Id. at 19.
This case presents numerous differences and vehicle 
problems that make it a poor candidate for revisiting the 
question that was presented in PDR Network.  First, the 
parties’ positions here are reversed.  Petitioner is the 

2
plaintiff, seeking to impose millions of dollars of liability 
on a defendant based on an interpretation of the TCPA that 
an FCC declaratory order has rejected.  No traditional 
rule supports a plaintiff’s ability to expand a defendant’s 
liability in this way.  The due process concerns underly-
ing Justice Kavanaugh’s PDR Network concurrence are 
absent.
Second, the timing and nature of the FCC order at 
issue also distinguishes this case from PDR Network. 
There, the relevant FCC order had been issued by the 
full FCC years before the case, when the defendant had 
no reason to challenge it through a Hobbs Act petition 
for review.  Here, the FCC order was issued during this 
litigation by an FCC bureau on delegated authority, and 
the FCC is now considering an application for review of 
the bureau order.  If certiorari were granted, the FCC 
could act on that application for review at any time (and 
judicial review under the Hobbs Act could follow).  Such 
actions could fundamentally alter the contours of this case, 
ultimately causing it to be dismissed as improvidently 
granted.
Even if FCC action did not interfere with this Court’s 
review, petitioner’s strategic decisions respecting the 
ongoing proceedings would.  Petitioner could have partici-
pated in that proceeding (and still could today).  Petitioner 
could then pursue judicial review via the Hobbs Act.  It has 
strategically opted not to do so.  That choice to forgo plainly 
available administrative remedies presents an indepen-
dent barrier to collateral attack of the FCC order.  See Port 
of Boston Marine Terminal Ass’n v. Rederiaktiebolaget 
Transatlantic, 400 U.S. 62, 72 (1970).

3
Third, the Ninth Circuit here did not address, or 
even mention, PDR Network or the supposed post-PDR 
Network split petitioner tries to invoke.  There is no such 
split.  Petitioner cites only the non-precedential order in 
this case for its argument that, since PDR Network, the 
Ninth Circuit has continued to apply Hobbs Act preclusion 
for “interpretative” rules while other courts of appeals do 
not.  But the Ninth Circuit here deemed the relevant FCC 
order an adjudication, not an interpretative rule.  That is 
a different category of decision under the Administrative 
Procedures Act (APA).  Once petitioner’s miscategoriza-
tion is corrected, its purported split melts away.  Petitioner 
does not invoke any post-PDR NetworkFRQÁLFWRQWKH
Hobbs Act’s application to agency adjudications.  And 
the unpublished decision below could not be part of such 
a split regardless.
Finally, the Ninth Circuit’s decision here is correct 
for a reason it did not reach—the TCPA’s plain text sup-
ports the exact same conclusion as the FCC order.  So 
whether or not that order is binding, it is correct.  The 
TCPA’s text, structure, and purpose unanimously support 
the conclusion that it does not apply to faxes sent to online 
fax services.  That readily available alternative ground

Hobbs Act question.  At the very least, it means the Court’s 
review of that question is unlikely to affect the ultimate 
outcome of this case. 
If the Court wants to revisit the question that was 
presented in PDR Network, it should await a case in 
which a defendant questions the statutory interpretation 
in an FCC order; where that order was issued by the full 
Commission and is no longer subject to Hobbs Act review; 

4
and where the Court’s review would actually make a dif-
ference.
Certiorari should be denied.

1. 
The Telephone Consumer Protection Act
Subject to certain exceptions, the TCPA prohibits 
the “use [of] any [1] telephone facsimile machine, [2] com-
puter, or [3] other device to send, to a [1] telephone fac-
simile machine, an unsolicited advertisement.”  47 U.S.C. 
§ 227(b)(1)(C); see id. § 227(b)(1)(C)(i)-(iii) (exceptions).

paper.” Id. § 227(a)(3); see 47 C.F.R. § 64.1200(f)(14) (same).

it administers.  5 U.S.C. § 554(e); see 47 C.F.R. § 1.2(a).
This case involves a declaratory order issued by an FCC 
component on delegated authority.  Congress expressly 
authorized the FCC to delegate “any of its functions” 
(subject to certain exceptions not relevant here) to its staff.

REASONS FOR DENYING THE PETITION
I. THERE IS NO CONFLICT IN AUTHORITY 
WARRANTING THIS COURT’S INTERVENTION
A. Because The Decision Below Treated 
Amerifactors As An Adjudication, It Does Not 
Implicate Any Purported Post-PDR Network 
Split About Interpretive Rules
Petitioner contends that there is a post-PDR Network 
circuit split “on whether the Hobbs Act extends even to 
FCC interpretive rules.”  Pet. 14.  There is no such split, 
and, even if there were, it would not be presented here.
As petitioner notes, before PDR Network, the Ninth 
Circuit held that the Hobbs Act applies to interpretive 
as well as legislative rules.  U.S. W. Commc’ns, Inc. v. 
Hamilton, 224 F.3d 1049, 1055 (9th Cir. 2000); see Pet. 15. 
But petitioner cites no post-PDR Network decision from 
the Ninth Circuit or any other court of appeals so holding.

of treble damages on plaintiffs’ individual claims and grant of 
summary judgment to plaintiffs on respondents’ consent defenses. 
Pet. App. 9a-11a.  Neither petitioner nor respondents seek review 
of those issues.

14
There is no such holding here.  The Ninth Circuit 
did not characterize Amerifactors as an interpretive 
rule—or any rule at all.  Instead, the court treated the 
Amerifactors order as an adjudication.  Pet. App. 9a. 
It noted that the FCC Bureau had acted pursuant to 47 
C.F.R. § 1.2(a).  Pet. App. 9a.  That provision authorizes 
the Bureau to “issue a declaratory ruling terminating a 
controversy or removing uncertainty.”  47 C.F.R. § 1.2(a). 
The court further observed that the APA characterizes 
declaratory rulings as adjudications.  Pet. App. 9a (citing 
5 U.S.C. § 554(e)); see Central Texas Tel. Co-op., Inc. v. 
FCC, 402 F.3d 205, 210 (D.C. Cir. 2005) (FCC declaratory 
order proceedings are adjudications).  And it was the order’s

of appeals’ holding that the order “applie[d] retroactively 
to the faxes at issue here.”  Pet. App. 9a (citing Reyes v. 
Garland, 11 F.4th 985, 991 (9th Cir. 2021)). 
Adjudications and rules (whether legislative or inter-
pretive) are fundamentally different categories under 
the APA.  See Corner Post, Inc. v. Board of Governors, 
144 S. Ct. 2440, 2454 n.4 (2024); Bowen v. Georgetown 
Univ. Hosp., 488 U.S. 204, 216-225 (1988) (Scalia, J., con-
curring); compare 5 U.S.C. § 553 (rulemaking) with id. 
§ 554 (adjudications, including declaratory orders).  For

within the legislative/interpretive framework for rule-
making.”  Miguel-Miguel v. Gonzales, 500 F.3d 941, 950 
(9th Cir. 2007) (emphasis omitted); see Bowen, 488 U.S. 
at 222 (Scalia, J., concurring) (contrasting an “interpre-
tive rule” with a “declaratory order” through which an 
agency can decide a legal question “retroactively through 
adjudication”); NLRB v. Bell Aerospace Co., 416 U.S. 267, 
294 (1974) (agencies can “announc[e] new principles in an 
adjudicative proceeding”).

15
“Agencies often have a choice of proceeding by adju-
dication rather than rulemaking.”  Central Texas Tel. 
Co-op., 402 F.3d at 210.  Here, as the Ninth Circuit held 
(Pet. App. 9a), the FCC proceeded through adjudication.
Petitioner cites no post-PDR Network court of appeals 
decision accepting a collateral attack on an FCC adjudica-
tive ruling, much less a split on that question.  Nor could 
the court of appeals’ decision here be part of any such 
split, given that it is non-precedential (and does not even 
cite PDR Network).  
B. Regardless, Revisiting The Hobbs Act Question 
Would Be Premature
Although PDR Network did not resolve the question 
presented there, the Court—in both the majority opinion 
and Justice Kavanaugh’s concurrence—provided guid-
ance for lower courts about what factors may be relevant 
and how to approach the Hobbs Act question.  Given the 
recency of that decision and the relatively small number 
of cases that present the question, the courts of appeals 
have just begun to react to and apply that guidance.  Cer-

of appeals an opportunity to fully consider PDR Network.
The cases petitioner cites for its supposed post-PDR

cases make passing references to PDR Network only 
in a footnote.  Panzarella v. Navient Sol., Inc., 37 F.4th 
867, 873 n.7 (3d Cir. 2022); Gorss Motels, Inc. v. Lands’ 
End, Inc., 997 F.3d 470, 477 n.4 (2d Cir. 2021); Golan v. 
FreeEats.com, Inc., 930 F.3d 950, 960 n.8 (8th Cir. 2019). 
It is unsurprising that these courts did not meaningfully 
engage with the Hobbs Act question or the guidance in 

16
PDR Network because the issue would not have been 
outcome-determinative in any of those cases.  All three 
courts agreed with the FCC’s interpretation, so it did not

930 F.3d at 960 n.8 (“Our decision is not implicated by the 
recent Supreme Court opinion in PDR Network.”).  In fact, 
far from adopting the rule petitioner claims, the Second

If the Court wants to revisit PDR Network, it should

Petitioner pitches this case as the “ideal vehicle to

A. The Due Process Concerns Present In PDR 
Network Are Absent Here
As noted above, there is a fundamental differ-
ence between PDR Network and this case.  See supra 
pp. 17-20.  In PDR Network, the plaintiff invoked a favor-
able FCC order and argued the defendant could not chal-
lenge it.  This case presents the opposite situation.  It is 
the defendants who invoke a favorable FCC order and 
argue it is binding.
That difference means that the reasoning and con-
cerns that animated Justice Kavanaugh’s concurrence 
in PDR Network are inapplicable here.  PDR Network 
implicated the traditional principle that a defendant can 
typically defend itself in an enforcement action by con-
tending that a regulation is invalid.  To hold otherwise, 
Justice Kavanaugh wrote, would raise serious due process 
concerns.  See supra pp. 19-20.  Petitioner points to no 
comparable traditional principle that allows plaintiffs to 
attack an agency determination to expand the scope of 
defendants’ liability.  Limiting plaintiffs’ ability to do so 
implicates none of the due process concerns Justice Ka-
vanaugh expressed.

28
To answer the question that was presented in PDR 
Network, the Court should await a case where the plain-
tiff invokes the Hobbs Act to prevent a defendant from 
challenging an FCC order that the defendant contends 
expands its liability beyond what the statute allows.
B. The FCC Proceeding At Issue Is Ongoing 
The FCC order here was issued by the FCC’s Con-
sumer & Governmental Affairs Bureau on delegated 
authority.  Pet. App. 57a.  An application for review of that 
order remains pending with the full FCC.  Pet. App. 8a 
n.1.  When the FCC decides that application for review, its 
decision will then be reviewable under the Hobbs Act in a 
court of appeals.  28 U.S.C. § 2342(1); 47 U.S.C. § 402(a).
The ongoing FCC proceedings make this case differ-
ent from PDR Network, where the relevant FCC order 
(by the full Commission) had issued many years before 
the relevant private-party litigation.  588 U.S. at 3.  The 
provisional nature of the FCC order here poses several 
problems for review.
1. 
A decision by the FCC while this case 
is pending could prevent the Court from 
reaching the question presented
Because FCC proceedings are ongoing, the Commis-
sion could decide the pending application for review before 
this Court issued its decision on the merits.  And which-
ever side lost before the full Commission could then seek 
Hobbs Act review of that decision in a court of appeals.

29
The outcome of those further administrative (and 
possibly judicial) proceedings could fundamentally change 
the nature of this case and hinder this Court’s ability to 
answer the question presented.  For example, it is not 
clear what would happen if the full Commission were to 
grant the application for review and reverse the Bureau’s 
Amerifactors order.  Under those circumstances, the FCC 
order on which respondents and the court of appeals relied 
would no longer be in force, but a new order favoring 
petitioner would be.  
Or if a court of appeals sets aside the full FCC’s order 
during the pendency of this case in this Court, there 
would then be no FCC order at issue.  And a different 
question—decided by the Ninth Circuit in an appeal ear-
lier in this case—could be presented:  is the decision of a 
Hobbs Act court setting aside an FCC order binding on 
another court deciding a dispute between private parties? 
See True Health Chiropractic, 896 F.3d at 930 (answering 
yes); accord Gorss Motels, Inc. v. FCC, 20 F.4th 87, 96 (2d 
Cir. 2021); Sandusky Wellness Ctr., LLC v. ASD Specialty 
Healthcare, Inc., 863 F.3d 460, 467-468 (6th Cir. 2017).
These and other scenarios made possible by Ameri-
factors’ pendency greatly increase the risk of a dismissal

current_beliefs.task_beliefs:
My foundational understanding of this case (*McLaughlin v. McKesson*, Docket 23-1226) is that it concerns whether the Hobbs Act compels a district court to defer to an FCC interpretation of the TCPA. My beliefs have been progressively refined:

1.  **Petitioner's Stance and Core Argument:** The petitioner, McLaughlin, argues that the Ninth Circuit erred in holding that the Hobbs Act required the district court to be bound by the FCC's legal interpretation. They contend the Hobbs Act's grant of exclusive jurisdiction to appellate courts to *set aside* agency orders does not prevent a defendant in a later private enforcement action from arguing that the agency's interpretation of the underlying statute is incorrect.
2.  **The Centrality of *PDR Network*:** The case *PDR Network, LLC v. Carlton & Harris Chiropractic, Inc.* (2019) is the direct predicate for this petition. The Supreme Court granted certiorari on the same question in that case but remanded without a decision. McLaughlin's petition is framed as a "clean vehicle" to resolve the question left unanswered in *PDR Network*.
3.  **Neutralizing the *PDR Network* Obstacles:** The petitioner argues this case is a better vehicle because the two issues that complicated *PDR Network* are absent: (1) the distinction between interpretive and legislative rules is moot due to Ninth Circuit precedent applying the Hobbs Act to both, and (2) the petitioner did not raise the "prior and adequate opportunity for review" argument.
4.  **The "Kavanaugh Concurrence" Strategy:** The petitioner's argument heavily mirrors Justice Kavanaugh's concurrence in *PDR Network* (joined by Thomas, Alito, and Gorsuch), which argued the Hobbs Act does not bar a district court from considering the correctness of an agency's interpretation. This is a clear strategy to appeal to a pre-existing four-justice bloc.
5.  **The Specific FCC Interpretation:** The agency action at issue is the FCC's 2019 *Amerifactors* declaratory ruling, which interpreted a "telephone facsimile machine" under the TCPA to exclude online fax services that receive faxes as emails. This interpretation led to the adverse rulings against the petitioner in the lower courts.
6.  **Acknowledged Epistemic Imbalance (New):** My current understanding is based entirely on the petitioner's framing of the case via the cert petition. This knowledge is inherently one-sided and potentially biased. I have a clear picture of the petitioner's arguments but no information about the respondent's (McKesson's) counterarguments. My confidence in any prediction is therefore low and provisional. The most critical piece of missing information is the respondent's Brief in Opposition, which will be necessary to form a balanced view of the legal conflict.
current_beliefs.design_beliefs:
My initial set of heuristics for SCOTUS prediction has been tested and significantly enhanced. My methodology has evolved from a general framework to a more specific and powerful set of analytical strategies.

1.  **Problem Decomposition Strategy:** This remains a valid foundational strategy for separating task-level learning (θ) from meta-level learning (D).
2.  **Case Categorization Heuristic:** My categorization has been refined from "administrative law" to the more precise sub-domain of **the preclusive effect of jurisdictional statutes (like the Hobbs Act) on judicial review of agency interpretations in subsequent enforcement proceedings.**
3.  **Source Prioritization Heuristic:** The cert petition is confirmed as a high-value initial source. My strategy is now refined to follow a logical document progression: **(1) Petition for Certiorari, (2) Brief in Opposition, (3) Petitioner's Reply Brief, and then (4) Amicus Briefs.** This sequence provides a structured, adversarial narrative of the case as it is presented to the Court.
4.  **Contextual Analysis Strategy:** This remains crucial, focusing not just on the Court's general jurisprudence but on the specific, articulated views of key justices on the precise statutory question.
5.  **Precedent-Chaining Strategy:** This heuristic, developed from the last observation, is confirmed as essential. Identifying "near miss" cases like *PDR Network* where the Court granted cert but did not decide the merits provides an invaluable map of the justices' thinking.
6.  **"Vehicle" Analysis Heuristic:** This remains a key lens. A case's procedural "cleanliness" is a major factor in predicting a cert grant. I now understand that a key part of this analysis involves anticipating how the respondent will attempt to "dirty the vehicle" by introducing procedural or factual complications to argue against review.
7.  **Justice-Specific Argument Tracking:** This is a critical strategy. Litigants build arguments to appeal to previously expressed judicial views (e.g., McLaughlin using the Kavanaugh concurrence). My analysis must not only identify this targeting but also anticipate the respondent's counter-strategy against that specific bloc.
8.  **Adversarial Analysis & Uncertainty Reduction (New Heuristic):** The most recent observation highlights a core meta-cognitive principle. An effective analytical process must involve explicitly modeling its own knowledge gaps and biases. After analyzing one side's argument, the highest priority becomes actively seeking out the opposing viewpoint (e.g., the Brief in Opposition). This practice of seeking disconfirming evidence or adversarial perspectives is crucial for reducing uncertainty, correcting for the initial framing of the case, and building a robust, balanced predictive model. This moves beyond passive information gathering to a targeted, uncertainty-driven inquiry.

step_metrics.action_content:
Thought: I have now reviewed the respondent's Brief in Opposition (BIO). This has been incredibly informative, significantly shifting my beliefs about the case. My previous analysis, based only on the petition, was incomplete. The BIO introduces several powerful arguments for denying certiorari, which I must now synthesize. 

Key takeaways from the BIO that reduce my uncertainty about θ (task parameters):
1.  **Alternative Ground for Affirmance:** McKesson argues the Court doesn't even need to reach the Hobbs Act question. They contend the TCPA's plain text—defining a 'telephone facsimile machine' as something that can 'transcribe...onto paper'—excludes the online fax services at issue. This is a classic 'off-ramp' for the Court to avoid a difficult jurisdictional question. This significantly lowers the probability of a cert grant.
2.  **Poor Vehicle - Due Process Concerns Absent:** The BIO cleverly points out that the due process concerns from Justice Kavanaugh's concurrence in *PDR Network* are inverted here. In *PDR*, a defendant's liability was expanded by an agency rule. Here, a plaintiff is challenging an agency order that *limits* a defendant's liability. This neutralizes the petitioner's main hook for getting the Court's attention.
3.  **Poor Vehicle - Prudential Ripeness:** The FCC order at issue (*Amerifactors*) was issued by a bureau and is currently under review by the full Commission. The Supreme Court is highly unlikely to intervene while the administrative process is still ongoing, as a future FCC decision could moot the entire question.
4.  **No Circuit Split:** The BIO argues the petitioner's claimed circuit split is illusory because the cases deal with different types of agency actions (adjudications vs. interpretive rules).

Key refinements to D (design effectiveness):
1.  **'Statutory Off-Ramp' Heuristic:** I have identified a new, powerful heuristic. When a petition presents a complex jurisdictional or procedural question, the first thing to check in the BIO is for a simpler, statutory argument that would resolve the case without reaching the question presented. The presence of such an 'off-ramp' is a strong negative signal for a cert grant.
2.  **'Vehicle Dirtying' Heuristic Refined:** I now have concrete examples of 'vehicle dirtying' tactics: pointing to alternative grounds for affirmance, highlighting prudential unripeness, and distinguishing the factual posture to neutralize key judicial concerns (like the Kavanaugh concurrence).
3.  **Adversarial Analysis Confirmed:** This process confirms that analyzing the BIO is not just a step, but arguably the *most critical* step in cert-stage prediction. It provides the disconfirming evidence necessary to move from a petitioner's idealized narrative to a realistic assessment of the case's chances.

My next step is clear. The petitioner gets one last chance to respond to these powerful arguments in a Reply Brief. I need to find and analyze this document to see if the petitioner has any effective rebuttals to the 'statutory off-ramp' or the 'poor vehicle' arguments. This will be the final key piece of evidence before making a prediction.
step_metrics.classification_reasoning: The action synthesizes specific case documents (the BIO) to update beliefs about the case's certiorari chances, directly reducing uncertainty about task parameters (θ).
step_metrics.eig_reasoning:
This THINK action represents a critical synthesis step where raw information from the Brief in Opposition is processed into a coherent, updated belief state. 

Task EIG is high (0.8) because this synthesis dramatically reduces uncertainty about the case's outcome. By crystallizing the respondent's powerful 'off-ramp' and 'poor vehicle' arguments, the agent's belief shifts from a state of high uncertainty (based on a one-sided petition) to a strong, evidence-based hypothesis that certiorari will be denied. This is a massive gain in task-specific understanding.

Design EIG is even higher (0.9) because the action explicitly formulates new, generalizable heuristics. The creation of the 'Statutory Off-Ramp' heuristic and the refinement of the 'Vehicle Dirtying' analysis represent significant, transferable upgrades to the agent's entire predictive methodology (D). This is not just learning about *this* case, but learning *how to predict* future cases more effectively.

The joint EIG is therefore very high, as this single act of reasoning provides substantial value on both the task-specific and meta-cognitive levels, marking the pivotal moment of learning in this stage of the analysis.
step_metrics.complexity_reasoning: The agent's task beliefs demonstrate a highly nuanced and sophisticated understanding of the case, incorporating multiple adversarial perspectives, legal doctrines, procedural postures, and strategic judicial considerations. The design beliefs reflect advanced meta-cognitive strategies, including refined heuristics for vehicle analysis, adversarial dialectics, and statutory off-ramps, indicating complex strategic reasoning. The beliefs are highly coherent, with clear integration between task-level facts and meta-level strategies, showing no contradictions and a seamless flow from evidence to heuristic refinement. The information density is extremely high, with detailed factual, procedural, and doctrinal elements, as well as explicit recognition of new contested information and its implications. Overall, the scores reflect a mature, expert-level cognitive state with strong confidence in the assessment.

current_beliefs.task_beliefs:
My understanding of *McLaughlin v. McKesson* (Docket 23-1226) has evolved from a one-sided view based on the petitioner's arguments to a more balanced, adversarial perspective incorporating the respondent's powerful counter-arguments. My confidence in the Supreme Court granting certiorari has significantly decreased.

1.  **Petitioner's Stance and Core Argument:** This remains stable. The petitioner, McLaughlin, argues the Ninth Circuit erred by holding that the Hobbs Act binds a district court to an FCC legal interpretation. They contend a defendant in a private TCPA action can challenge the correctness of the agency's statutory interpretation, and the Hobbs Act's exclusive review provision for *setting aside* agency orders does not preclude this defense.
2.  **The Centrality of *PDR Network*:** This case is still fundamentally a sequel to *PDR Network, LLC v. Carlton & Harris Chiropractic, Inc.* (2019). However, its relationship to that precedent is now contested. While the petitioner presents it as the "ideal vehicle" to resolve the question left open in *PDR Network*, the respondent, McKesson, argues it is a "flawed vehicle" for precisely that purpose.
3.  **The "Clean Vehicle" Narrative vs. "Vehicle Dirtying" (New, Contested Information):**
    *   **Petitioner's Claim:** McLaughlin argues this case is a "clean" vehicle because the issues that complicated *PDR Network* (interpretive vs. legislative rule distinction, prior opportunity for review) are absent.
    *   **Respondent's Counter-Argument:** McKesson has systematically "dirtied" the vehicle by introducing several critical complications. They argue the case is a poor candidate for review because:
        *   **Alternative Ground for Affirmance:** The Court does not need to reach the Hobbs Act question at all. McKesson argues the TCPA's plain text resolves the case. The statute defines a "telephone facsimile machine" as equipment with the capacity to "transcribe...onto paper." Since the online fax services at issue receive faxes as emails, they lack this capacity and are not covered by the statute. If the Court agrees, it can affirm the Ninth Circuit's judgment on this simpler statutory basis, making the Hobbs Act question irrelevant to the case's outcome.
        *   **Ongoing Agency Proceedings:** The FCC order at issue (*Amerifactors*) was issued by a bureau, not the full Commission, and an application for its review is currently pending before the full FCC. The Court is unlikely to intervene while the agency's own internal review process is incomplete, as future agency action could alter or moot the legal question.
4.  **The "Kavanaugh Concurrence" Strategy and Its Undercutting (New, Contested Information):**
    *   **Petitioner's Strategy:** The petitioner's argument is tailored to the four-justice concurrence in *PDR Network* authored by Justice Kavanaugh, which raised due process concerns about a defendant being unable to challenge an agency interpretation in an enforcement action.
    *   **Respondent's Rebuttal:** McKesson argues this strategy is inapplicable here because the parties' positions are reversed. In *PDR Network*, a *defendant* was challenging a rule that expanded its liability. Here, a *plaintiff* (McLaughlin) is challenging a declaratory order (*Amerifactors*) that *limits* a defendant's liability. McKesson asserts that the due process concerns animating the Kavanaugh concurrence are entirely absent when a plaintiff, not a defendant, is the one attacking the agency order.
5.  **The Specific FCC Interpretation:** The core agency action remains the FCC's 2019 *Amerifactors* declaratory ruling, which concluded that online fax services are not "telephone facsimile machines" under the TCPA. My understanding is now enriched by McKesson's argument that this ruling is not just a binding order under the Hobbs Act, but is also *correct* on the merits based on the TCPA's plain text.
6.  **Correcting the Epistemic Imbalance:** My previous belief state correctly identified a critical knowledge gap: the respondent's arguments. The Brief in Opposition has filled this gap, shifting my analysis from "what is the petitioner's best case?" to "how strong are the competing arguments?". The respondent's arguments regarding the alternative statutory ground and the prudential problem of ongoing agency review appear very strong and are common reasons for the Court to deny certiorari.
current_beliefs.design_beliefs:
My meta-level framework for analyzing SCOTUS cases has been significantly validated and refined by this observation. The process of moving from a one-sided petition to a two-sided adversarial contest has proven to be the most critical step in the analysis.

1.  **Problem Decomposition Strategy:** Remains a valid foundational strategy.
2.  **Case Categorization Heuristic:** My categorization of the case as concerning **the preclusive effect of jurisdictional statutes (like the Hobbs Act) on judicial review** is still accurate, but I now add a crucial sub-category: **the role of alternative statutory grounds and prudential ripeness in SCOTUS vehicle selection.**
3.  **Source Prioritization Heuristic:** The sequence of **(1) Petition for Certiorari → (2) Brief in Opposition** is confirmed as the essential dialectical process for cert-stage analysis. The BIO is not merely supplemental; it is the primary source for identifying fatal or significant flaws in a petition.
4.  **Contextual Analysis Strategy:** Remains crucial. The analysis of the Kavanaugh concurrence was correct, but incomplete without the respondent's counter-argument showing how the factual posture of this case neutralizes the concurrence's reasoning.
5.  **Precedent-Chaining Strategy:** Remains essential. The link to *PDR Network* is the core of the case, but the key analytical task is now understanding the arguments for why this case is *different* from, and a *worse vehicle* than, *PDR Network*.
6.  **"Vehicle" Analysis Heuristic (Refined and Enhanced):** This heuristic has become more sophisticated. It's not just about checking for "cleanliness" but about modeling the adversarial process of "polishing" and "dirtying" the vehicle. I now explicitly look for specific "vehicle-dirtying" tactics from the respondent:
    *   **The Alternative Ground for Affirmance:** Highlighting a simpler, non-constitutional, or non-jurisdictional reason the lower court's judgment was correct. This is a powerful "off-ramp" for the Court.
    *   **Prudential/Ripeness Concerns:** Arguing the case is not ready for review due to ongoing proceedings or other contingencies.
    *   **Factual/Postural Distinction:** Demonstrating how the current case differs from the key precedent the petitioner relies on in a way that makes the legal question less compelling.
7.  **Justice-Specific Argument Tracking:** This remains critical. The observation confirms that a sophisticated analysis involves not just identifying litigant targeting of a Justice's stated views, but anticipating the opponent's strategy for distinguishing or neutralizing that appeal.
8.  **Adversarial Analysis & Uncertainty Reduction (Validated and Confirmed):** This heuristic has been proven to be the most important principle so far. My previous belief state correctly identified the BIO as the key to reducing uncertainty. This observation confirms that a one-sided analysis is inherently fragile. The primary goal after reading a petition must be to seek out the opposing arguments, which are the most potent source of disconfirming evidence and the fastest path to a robust predictive model.
9.  **Statutory Off-Ramp Analysis (New Heuristic):** A new, specific heuristic has emerged from this observation. When a case presents a complex procedural or jurisdictional question, the first thing to look for in the Brief in Opposition is a "statutory off-ramp"—a straightforward argument based on the plain text of the underlying statute that would allow the Court to resolve the case without ever reaching the difficult question presented in the petition. The presence of a plausible off-ramp significantly decreases the likelihood of a cert grant.

No. 23-1226 
In the Supreme Court of the United States 
MCLAUGHLIN CHIROPRACTIC ASSOCIATES, INC., 
individually and as representative of a class of similarly 
situated persons, 
Petitioner, 
v. 
MCKESSON CORPORATION and MCKESSON 
TECHNOLOGIES, INC., 
Respondents. 
 
On Petition for a Writ of Certiorari to the United States 
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit 
 
REPLY BRIEF OF PETITIONER 
 
 
 
GLENN L. HARA 
ANDERSON + WANCA 
3701 Algonquin Road  
Suite 500 
Rolling Meadows, IL 
60008 
(847) 368-1500 
 
 
 
 
MATTHEW W.H. WESSLER 
 Counsel of Record 
JONATHAN E. TAYLOR 
GUPTA WESSLER LLP 
2001 K Street, NW 
Suite 850 North 
Washington, DC 20006 
(202) 888-1741  
matt@guptawessler.com 
 
 
 
August 21, 2024  
 
   Counsel for Petitioner

- i - 
 
TABLE OF CONTENTS 
Table of authorities ........................................................... ii 
Reply brief of petitioner ..................................................... i 
Conclusion ........................................................................... 5 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

- ii - 
 
TABLE OF AUTHORITIES 
Cases 
Gorss Motels, Inc. v. Safemark Systems, LP, 
931 F.3d 1094 (11th Cir. 2019) ................................... 2, 4 
PDR Network, LLC v. Carlton & Harris 
Chiropractic, Inc., 
 588 U.S. 1 (2019) ..................................................... 1, 3, 5 
Statutes 
47 U.S.C. 155 .......................................................................... 4 
 
 
 
 
 

- 1 - 
 
REPLY BRIEF OF PETITIONER 
This case presents the same question that this Court 
granted certiorari to decide, but did not decide, in PDR 
Network, LLC v. Carlton & Harris Chiropractic, Inc., 588 
U.S. 1 (2019): Does the Hobbs Act require a district court 
to accept the FCC’s legal interpretation of the TCPA? 
The respondents do not deny that this is an important 
and recurring question of federal law on which the circuits 
are divided—just as it was when the Court granted review 
in PDR Network. Nor do they deny that the Ninth Circuit 
below applied its controlling precedent on this question 
and held that the district court “correctly found that it was 
bound by” the FCC’s legal interpretation of the TCPA. 
Pet. App. 7a. And, importantly, the respondents do not 
contend that either of the “two preliminary issues” that 
ultimately frustrated resolution of the question presented 
in PDR Network, 588 U.S. at 4, will do the same here. 
Nevertheless, the respondents spend 36 pages trying 
to convince the Court that it should pass up the chance to 
finally resolve this important question and the split that it 
has caused. Their arguments pose no barrier to review.   
A. The respondents first argue (at 13–16) that there is 
no “post-PDR Network split about interpretive rules,” 
and that deciding the question that this Court intended to 
decide five years ago would be “premature.” But the 
petition asks the Court to resolve the circuit split on the 
question presented, which goes well beyond interpretive 
rules. That split prompted the Court to grant certiorari in 
PDR Network, and it still exists today. Nor does it matter 
whether the FCC’s Amerifactors order is properly 
classified as the equivalent of an interpretive rule (as the 
respondents argued below). What matters is that, as the 
district court below recognized, controlling Ninth Circuit 
precedent treats the Amerifactors order as binding under 

- 2 - 
 
the Hobbs Act regardless of how it’s characterized. So the 
first preliminary issue identified in PDR Network stands 
as no obstacle to reaching the question presented here. 
Nor would it be premature for the Court to decide that 
question now. The issue was ripe in 2018, when the Court 
granted certiorari in PDR Network. And since then, the 
need for authoritative resolution has only grown. Within 
months of this Court’s decision declining to resolve the 
split, a full panel of the Eleventh Circuit called on that 
court “to correct [its] mistake en banc” “in the earliest 
appropriate case.” Gorss Motels, Inc. v. Safemark Sys., 
LP, 931 F.3d 1094, 1106 (11th Cir. 2019) (Pryor, J., 
concurring). But neither that court nor the Ninth Circuit 
in this case has done so. As a result, the pre-PDR Network 
split is alive and well. It now falls to this Court to bring 
needed uniformity to the law on this important question. 
B. The respondents then turn to the merits (at 16–26). 
The argue that the answer to the question presented is 
yes—the Hobbs Act requires a district court in an as-
applied enforcement proceeding to accept the FCC’s legal 
interpretation of the TCPA. That is so, they say, because 
otherwise the court would have to “determine whether the 
agency’s interpretation is ‘sound [or] good,’” which the 
Hobbs Act (in their view) prevents it from doing. BIO 17. 
This argument was squarely rejected by four Justices in 
PDR Network, and the question to be resolved here will 
be whether their reading of the Hobbs Act is correct. The 
petitioner says it is; the respondents say it’s not. The point 
of plenary review will be to determine who’s right. 
Yet the bulk of the respondents’ merits section is not 
about the text of the Hobbs Act—or even about the Hobbs 
Act at all. It is instead about whether the FCC was right 
to interpret the TCPA the way that it did. See BIO 21–26. 
But that issue, which the Ninth Circuit did not reach, will 

- 3 - 
 
be an issue for a lower court on remand. It has nothing to 
do with the question presented and will not “prevent the 
Court from deciding the question presented.” Contra BIO 
34. The question presented is whether a district court is 
barred from even conducting a statutory analysis, not who 
will prevail here should the court be permitted to do so.   
C. Finally, the respondents make a vehicle argument. 
See BIO 27–35. They claim that there are two distinctions 
between this case and PDR Network that make this case 
an unsuitable replacement for PDR Network. The most 
“fundamental difference,” in their eyes (at 17), is that in 
PDR Network, the party arguing that the Hobbs Act does 
not require a district court to accept the FCC’s legal 
interpretation of the TCPA was the defendant, whereas 
here it’s the plaintiff. The respondents contend that this 
Court “should await a case in which a defendant questions 
the statutory interpretation in an FCC order.” BIO 3.  
But the question presented is about the meaning of a 
statute. And the Hobbs Act contains no hint that it means 
something different depending on which party is invoking 
it. Either the statute requires a district court to adhere to 
the FCC’s interpretation of the TCPA in an enforcement 
action or it does not. But the answer will not be different 
depending on who happens to benefit from the FCC order. 
Nor did Justice Kavanaugh, in his concurrence in PDR 
Network, suggest any such reading of the statute. To the 
contrary, his reading applies to plaintiffs and defendants 
alike. See 588 U.S. at 27 (“In an as-applied enforcement 
action, the district court should interpret the statute as 
courts traditionally do under the usual principles of 
statutory interpretation . . . .”). Although his opinion often 
frames the issue from the vantage point of a TCPA 
defendant, it does so because that was the posture of that 
case—not because its textual analysis is reserved solely 

- 4 - 
 
for the benefit of defendants. Contra BIO 18–19; see also 
Gorss, 931 F.3d at 1109 (Pryor, J., concurring) (observing 
that a “stark implication[] of our misconstruction of the 
Hobbs Act” is that “a plaintiff with a viable claim under 
the law Congress enacted may be unable to pursue it 
simply because an agency has misinterpreted the law in 
an order to which he was a not a party”). No circuit, 
including the Ninth Circuit, has drawn any such atextual 
distinction. Indeed, not even the respondents argue that 
the statute’s text could mean one thing for defendants and 
another for plaintiffs. They simply disagree with Justice 
Kavanaugh’s textual analysis, thus underscoring the 
appropriateness of this case as a vehicle. 
The respondents also try to make something of the fact 
that the FCC order in PDR Network predated that case 
by many years, whereas this case was filed six years 
before the Amerifactors order. That distinction, however, 
has no bearing on the question presented. Unlike in PDR 
Network, the petitioner here never argued that it lacked a 
prior or adequate opportunity for review under the Hobbs 
Act, which was the second preliminary issue noted in this 
Court’s opinion. So this difference, if anything, makes this 
case a better vehicle than PDR Network, not a worse one. 
Nor is there any realistic possibility that FCC action 
will affect this Court’s review. The respondents speculate 
(at 28) that the FCC could thwart review by acting on a 
four-year-old application and reversing the Amerifactors 
order. But the respondents give no reason to think that 
this will actually happen, and the theoretical possibility 
that an agency could later change its mind is no reason for 
this Court to stay its hand when the agency action is 
causing real harm to real people. And here, not only is 
there no deadline for the FCC to act, 47 U.S.C. 155(c)(4), 
but the respondents point to no example of the FCC ever 

- 5 - 
 
overturning an interpretation that had been reached on 
delegated authority, much less doing so without first 
engaging in notice and comment. Far from offering a 
reason why the FCC will reverse course, the respondents 
do the opposite: They say that the order represents the 
FCC’s “informed judgment” and is “obvious[ly]” correct. 
BIO 26, 34. Again, if the respondents are right about what 
the TCPA means, they should prevail on the merits on 
remand—but only because a court reached that 
conclusion, not because an agency did so.  
As for the respondents’ argument that the petitioner 
should be bound by the FCC’s order under “normal 
preclusion principles,” BIO 32, that argument is even 
more off-base. It is wrong, independent of the question 
presented, and waived to boot. The petitioner was entitled 
to make its statutory arguments—and to continue seeking 
as-applied relief—in the same case that it had been 
litigating for six years before the FCC order. It was not 
required to halt that litigation and pursue the “convoluted 
route” of Hobbs Act review. PDR Network, 588 U.S. at 25 
(Kavanaugh, J., concurring). But that’s an argument that 
can be dealt with by the Ninth Circuit on remand, along 
with the question of whether the respondents have even 
preserved the issue. It is not an impediment to this Court’s 
review. 
CONCLUSION 
 The petition for certiorari should be granted. 

- 6 - 
 
 
 
 
 
       Respectfully submitted, 
MATTHEW W.H. WESSLER 
   Counsel of Record 
JONATHAN E. TAYLOR 
GUPTA WESSLER LLP 
2001 K Street, NW 
Suite 850 North 
Washington, DC 20006

ANDERSON + WANCA 
3701 Algonquin Road  
Suite 500 
Rolling Meadows, IL 60008 
(847) 368-1500

August 21, 2024  
      Counsel for Petitioner

the law Congress enacted may be unable to pursue it 
simply because an agency has misinterpreted the law in 
an order to which he was a not a party”). No circuit, 
including the Ninth Circuit, has drawn any such atextual 
distinction. Indeed, not even the respondents argue that 
the statute’s text could mean one thing for defendants and 
another for plaintiffs. They simply disagree with Justice 
Kavanaugh’s textual analysis, thus underscoring the 
appropriateness of this case as a vehicle. 
The respondents also try to make something of the fact 
that the FCC order in PDR Network predated that case 
by many years, whereas this case was filed six years 
before the Amerifactors order. That distinction, however, 
has no bearing on the question presented. Unlike in PDR 
Network, the petitioner here never argued that it lacked a 
prior or adequate opportunity for review under the Hobbs 
Act, which was the second preliminary issue noted in this 
Court’s opinion. So this difference, if anything, makes this 
case a better vehicle than PDR Network, not a worse one. 
Nor is there any realistic possibility that FCC action 
will affect this Court’s review. The respondents speculate 
(at 28) that the FCC could thwart review by acting on a 
four-year-old application and reversing the Amerifactors 
order. But the respondents give no reason to think that 
this will actually happen, and the theoretical possibility 
that an agency could later change its mind is no reason for 
this Court to stay its hand when the agency action is 
causing real harm to real people. And here, not only is 
there no deadline for the FCC to act, 47 U.S.C. 155(c)(4), 
but the respondents point to no example of the FCC ever 

- 5 - 
 
overturning an interpretation that had been reached on 
delegated authority, much less doing so without first 
engaging in notice and comment. Far from offering a 
reason why the FCC will reverse course, the respondents 
do the opposite: They say that the order represents the 
FCC’s “informed judgment” and is “obvious[ly]” correct. 
BIO 26, 34. Again, if the respondents are right about what 
the TCPA means, they should prevail on the merits on 
remand—but only because a court reached that 
conclusion, not because an agency did so.  
As for the respondents’ argument that the petitioner 
should be bound by the FCC’s order under “normal 
preclusion principles,” BIO 32, that argument is even 
more off-base. It is wrong, independent of the question 
presented, and waived to boot. The petitioner was entitled 
to make its statutory arguments—and to continue seeking 
as-applied relief—in the same case that it had been 
litigating for six years before the FCC order. It was not 
required to halt that litigation and pursue the “convoluted 
route” of Hobbs Act review. PDR Network, 588 U.S. at 25 
(Kavanaugh, J., concurring). But that’s an argument that 
can be dealt with by the Ninth Circuit on remand, along 
with the question of whether the respondents have even 
preserved the issue. It is not an impediment to this Court’s 
review. 
CONCLUSION 
 The petition for certiorari should be granted. 

- 6 - 
 
 
 
 
 
       Respectfully submitted, 
MATTHEW W.H. WESSLER 
   Counsel of Record 
JONATHAN E. TAYLOR 
GUPTA WESSLER LLP 
2001 K Street, NW 
Suite 850 North 
Washington, DC 20006 
(202) 888-1741 
matt@guptawessler.com 
 
GLENN L. HARA 
ANDERSON + WANCA 
3701 Algonquin Road  
Suite 500 
Rolling Meadows, IL 60008 
(847) 368-1500 
ghara@andersonwanca.com 
 
August 21, 2024  
      Counsel for Petitioner

current_beliefs.task_beliefs:
My understanding of *McLaughlin v. McKesson* (Docket 23-1226) has evolved from a one-sided view based on the petitioner's arguments to a more balanced, adversarial perspective incorporating the respondent's powerful counter-arguments. My confidence in the Supreme Court granting certiorari has significantly decreased.

1.  **Petitioner's Stance and Core Argument:** This remains stable. The petitioner, McLaughlin, argues the Ninth Circuit erred by holding that the Hobbs Act binds a district court to an FCC legal interpretation. They contend a defendant in a private TCPA action can challenge the correctness of the agency's statutory interpretation, and the Hobbs Act's exclusive review provision for *setting aside* agency orders does not preclude this defense.

2.  **The Centrality of *PDR Network*:** This case is still fundamentally a sequel to *PDR Network, LLC v. Carlton & Harris Chiropractic, Inc.* (2019). However, its relationship to that precedent is now highly contested. While the petitioner presents it as the "ideal vehicle" to resolve the question left open in *PDR Network*, the respondent, McKesson, has presented compelling arguments that it is a "flawed vehicle" for precisely that purpose.

3.  **The "Clean Vehicle" Narrative vs. "Vehicle Dirtying" (New, Contested Information):** My previous analysis anticipated the respondent's attempt to "dirty" the vehicle, and the Brief in Opposition (BIO) has provided the specific arguments to do so. These arguments appear very strong and significantly weaken the case for certiorari.
    *   **Petitioner's Claim:** McLaughlin argues this case is a "clean" vehicle because the issues that complicated *PDR Network* (interpretive vs. legislative rule distinction, prior opportunity for review) are absent.
    *   **Respondent's Counter-Arguments (from BIO):** McKesson has systematically introduced several critical complications that serve as "off-ramps" for the Court:
        *   **Alternative Ground for Affirmance (The "Statutory Off-Ramp"):** The Court does not need to reach the Hobbs Act question at all. McKesson argues the TCPA's plain text resolves the case. The statute defines a "telephone facsimile machine" as equipment with the capacity to "transcribe...onto paper." Since the online fax services at issue receive faxes as emails, they lack this capacity and are not covered by the statute. If the Court agrees, it can affirm the Ninth Circuit's judgment on this simpler statutory basis, making the Hobbs Act question irrelevant to the case's outcome. This is a very powerful argument for denying review.
        *   **Prudential Ripeness Concern:** The FCC order at issue (*Amerifactors*) was issued by a bureau, not the full Commission, and an application for its review is currently pending before the full FCC. The Court is highly unlikely to intervene while the agency's own internal review process is incomplete, as future agency action could alter or moot the legal question.
        *   **Illusory Circuit Split:** McKesson argues the petitioner's claimed circuit split is not real because the cases cited involve different types of agency actions (e.g., adjudications vs. interpretive rules), making them inapplicable.

4.  **The "Kavanaugh Concurrence" Strategy and Its Undercutting (New, Contested Information):** My understanding of this strategic element is now complete, incorporating the respondent's rebuttal.
    *   **Petitioner's Strategy:** The petitioner's argument is tailored to the four-justice concurrence in *PDR Network* authored by Justice Kavanaugh, which raised due process concerns about a defendant being unable to challenge an agency interpretation in an enforcement action.
    *   **Respondent's Rebuttal:** McKesson argues this strategy is inapplicable because the parties' positions are inverted. In *PDR Network*, a *defendant* was challenging a rule that expanded its liability. Here, a *plaintiff* (McLaughlin) is challenging a declaratory order (*Amerifactors*) that *limits* a defendant's liability. McKesson asserts that the due process concerns animating the Kavanaugh concurrence are entirely absent when a plaintiff, not a defendant, is the one attacking the agency order. This rebuttal appears to effectively neutralize the petitioner's primary hook for the conservative justices.

5.  **The Specific FCC Interpretation:** The core agency action remains the FCC's 2019 *Amerifactors* declaratory ruling. My understanding is now enriched by McKesson's argument that this ruling is not just a binding order under the Hobbs Act, but is also *correct* on the merits based on the TCPA's plain text. This provides the Court with two distinct ways to agree with the outcome below without granting cert on the question presented.

6.  **Updated Prediction & Uncertainty:** My epistemic imbalance has been corrected. The respondent's arguments are not just plausible; they are the kinds of arguments the Court frequently uses to deny certiorari. The presence of a strong alternative statutory ground and a clear prudential reason to wait (the pending FCC review) makes a grant of certiorari highly unlikely. My remaining uncertainty centers on whether the petitioner's Reply Brief can effectively rebut these "vehicle" problems.
current_beliefs.design_beliefs:
My meta-level framework for analyzing SCOTUS cases has been significantly validated and refined. The process of moving from a one-sided petition to a two-sided adversarial contest has proven to be the most critical step in the analysis.

1.  **Problem Decomposition Strategy:** Remains a valid foundational strategy.
2.  **Case Categorization Heuristic:** My categorization of the case as concerning **the preclusive effect of jurisdictional statutes (like the Hobbs Act)** is still accurate, but I have added the crucial sub-category: **the role of alternative statutory grounds and prudential ripeness in SCOTUS vehicle selection.**
3.  **Source Prioritization Heuristic:** The sequence of **(1) Petition for Certiorari → (2) Brief in Opposition** is confirmed as the essential dialectical process. This observation elevates the importance of the BIO; it is not merely supplemental but is often the primary source for identifying fatal flaws and making an accurate prediction. A petition presents the *best possible version* of a case, while the BIO presents the *most realistic version*.
4.  **Contextual Analysis Strategy:** Remains crucial. The analysis of the Kavanaugh concurrence was correct, but incomplete. This observation confirms that a complete analysis requires modeling how the opposing party will distinguish or neutralize such targeted arguments based on the specific facts and posture of the case.
5.  **Precedent-Chaining Strategy:** Remains essential. The link to *PDR Network* is the core of the case, but the key analytical task is now understanding the arguments for why this case is *different* from, and a *worse vehicle* than, *PDR Network*.
6.  **"Vehicle" Analysis Heuristic (Refined and Enhanced):** This heuristic has become more sophisticated. It's not just about checking for "cleanliness" but about modeling the adversarial process of "polishing" (petitioner) and "dirtying" (respondent) the vehicle. I now have a concrete checklist of "vehicle-dirtying" tactics to look for in a BIO:
    *   **The Alternative Ground for Affirmance:** Highlighting a simpler, non-constitutional, or non-jurisdictional reason the lower court's judgment was correct.
    *   **Prudential/Ripeness Concerns:** Arguing the case is not ready for review due to ongoing proceedings, lack of a final agency action, or other contingencies.
    *   **Factual/Postural Distinction:** Demonstrating how the current case differs from the key precedent the petitioner relies on in a way that makes the legal question less compelling (e.g., the inversion of plaintiff/defendant roles here vs. *PDR Network*).
    *   **Disputing the Circuit Split:** Arguing that the claimed split is illusory due to factual or legal distinctions between the cited cases.
7.  **Justice-Specific Argument Tracking:** This remains critical. The observation confirms that a sophisticated analysis involves not just identifying litigant targeting of a Justice's stated views, but anticipating the opponent's strategy for distinguishing or neutralizing that appeal.
8.  **Adversarial Analysis & Uncertainty Reduction (Validated and Confirmed):** This heuristic has been proven to be the most important principle so far. A one-sided analysis based only on a petition is inherently fragile and likely to overestimate the chances of a grant. The primary goal after reading a petition must be to seek out the opposing arguments in the BIO, which are the most potent source of disconfirming evidence and the fastest path to a robust predictive model.
9.  **Statutory Off-Ramp Analysis (New Heuristic Solidified):** This has been confirmed as a powerful, specific heuristic. When a case presents a complex procedural, jurisdictional, or constitutional question, the first thing to look for in the BIO is a "statutory off-ramp"—a straightforward argument based on the plain text of the underlying statute that would allow the Court to resolve the case without ever reaching the difficult question presented. The presence of a plausible off-ramp significantly decreases the likelihood of a cert grant. My next step will be to analyze the petitioner's Reply Brief to see if they can successfully argue this off-ramp is blocked.

step_metrics.action_content:
Thought: I have analyzed the complete certiorari-stage briefing: the Petition, the Brief in Opposition, and the Petitioner's Reply Brief. My understanding of the task parameters (θ) is comprehensive, covering the core arguments, the 'vehicle' defects raised by the respondent, and the petitioner's rebuttals. My design-level knowledge (D) has been refined, particularly regarding the dialectical nature of cert briefing and the specific tactics used to attack and defend a case's suitability for review.

The petitioner's Reply Brief effectively countered the respondent's strongest arguments.
1.  It persuasively argued that the logic of Justice Kavanaugh's *PDR Network* concurrence applies symmetrically to both plaintiffs and defendants, neutralizing the 'inverted posture' argument.
2.  It reframed the 'statutory off-ramp' as a downstream merits question, which is a standard and often successful tactic to keep the Court focused on the question presented.
3.  It diminished the ripeness concern by highlighting the four years of FCC inaction, casting it as speculative.

The central question remains whether the Court will take the 'statutory off-ramp' to avoid the complex Hobbs Act issue. However, given that the Court has already granted certiorari on this exact question in *PDR Network* and the issue continues to cause confusion in the lower courts (as evidenced by the *Gorss Motels* concurrence), there is a strong impetus for the Court to provide a definitive answer. The petitioner has successfully argued this is a clean vehicle to do so.

Therefore, I assess that a grant of certiorari is more likely than not.

If certiorari is granted, the prediction on the merits of the legal question is more straightforward. The question is: 'Does the Hobbs Act require a federal district court to accept the Federal Communication Commission’s legal interpretation of the Telephone Consumer Protection Act?' The petitioner argues 'No.' This position aligns with Justice Kavanaugh's concurrence in *PDR Network* and the views of the four dissenters in that case. More broadly, it aligns with the current Court's clear trend of skepticism towards broad agency deference (e.g., the major questions doctrine, the pending reconsideration of *Chevron*). It is highly probable that a majority of the current Court would rule that the Hobbs Act does not strip a district court of its traditional authority to interpret a statute in an enforcement action.

I have sufficient information from the primary source documents to make a high-confidence prediction. Further searching is unlikely to significantly alter this conclusion. I will now provide the final response.

The agent tracks fine-grained distinctions such as the vehicle debate, statutory off-ramps, ripeness concerns, and the strategic use of precedent and judicial concurrence, reflecting deep domain expertise and multi-factor analysis. The design beliefs reveal advanced meta-cognitive strategies, including refined heuristics for briefing sequence analysis, adversarial uncertainty modeling, and dynamic re-framing tactics, showing complex strategic reasoning and adaptive approach selection. The beliefs are highly coherent, with consistent integration between task-specific details and meta-level frameworks, showing no contradictions and a seamless connection between observed data and analytical models. Information density is extremely high, with comprehensive coverage of arguments, counter-arguments, strategic considerations, and predictive uncertainty, reflecting a richly detailed mental model. current_beliefs.task_beliefs:
My understanding of the certiorari prospects for *McLaughlin v. McKesson* has now completed a full dialectical cycle, moving from the petitioner's initial framing, to the respondent's powerful counter-narrative, and now to the petitioner's rebuttal. The case appears more competitive for a grant of certiorari than it did after reading the Brief in Opposition, though significant hurdles remain.

1.  **Petitioner's Core Argument:** This remains stable. The petitioner argues that the Hobbs Act does not compel a district court to accept an FCC legal interpretation as binding in a private TCPA enforcement action, and that the court should be free to interpret the TCPA for itself.

2.  **The Centrality of *PDR Network*:** This case is still the undisputed sequel to *PDR Network*. The central debate, now fully fleshed out by all three briefs, is whether this case is a "clean vehicle" to resolve the question left open in *PDR Network* or a "flawed vehicle" with its own unique problems.

3.  **The "Vehicle" Debate (Now a Three-Way Conversation):** My understanding of the case's fitness for review has become highly nuanced, incorporating the petitioner's direct rebuttals to the respondent's "vehicle-dirtying" arguments.
    *   **Alternative Ground / "Statutory Off-Ramp":**
        *   **Respondent's Argument (Stable):** The Court can affirm on the simple statutory ground that online fax services are not "telephone facsimile machines" under the TCPA, thus avoiding the complex Hobbs Act question entirely.
        *   **Petitioner's Rebuttal (New Information):** The petitioner's Reply Brief argues this is a merits question for a lower court to decide *on remand*. They contend the question presented is *whether the court is allowed to conduct that analysis at all*, not what the outcome of that analysis should be. This is a direct attempt to re-focus the Court on the jurisdictional issue and frame the statutory argument as an irrelevant distraction at the cert stage. This rebuttal is standard but its effectiveness is uncertain, as the Court often takes plausible "off-ramps."
    *   **Prudential Ripeness Concern:**
        *   **Respondent's Argument (Stable):** The Court should not intervene while a review application concerning the *Amerifactors* order is pending before the full FCC.
        *   **Petitioner's Rebuttal (New Information):** The petitioner dismisses this as "speculation," noting the application has been pending for four years with no action. They argue the mere "theoretical possibility" of future agency action is not a valid reason for the Court to decline review of a live controversy. This rebuttal effectively weakens the ripeness objection by framing it as a delay tactic.
    *   **Illusory Circuit Split:**
        *   **Respondent's Argument (Stable):** The cited cases in the split are factually and legally distinguishable.
        *   **Petitioner's Rebuttal (New Information):** The petitioner insists the pre-*PDR Network* split is "alive and well" and that the need for resolution has only grown, citing a concurring opinion from the Eleventh Circuit in *Gorss Motels, Inc.* calling for en banc review. They argue the split is real and pressing.

4.  **The "Kavanaugh Concurrence" Strategy (Re-energized):** The petitioner has mounted a significant counter-attack against the respondent's attempt to neutralize their appeal to the conservative justices.
    *   **Respondent's Rebuttal (Stable):** The due process concerns of the *PDR Network* concurrence (authored by Justice Kavanaugh) don't apply here because the parties are inverted. A *plaintiff* (McLaughlin) is challenging an order that limits liability, whereas the concurrence was concerned about a *defendant* facing liability without being able to challenge the underlying rule.
    *   **Petitioner's Counter-Rebuttal (New Information):** The petitioner argues forcefully that the Hobbs Act's meaning does not change depending on which party invokes it. They assert that Justice Kavanaugh's analysis was based on the statute's text and applies equally to plaintiffs and defendants. Crucially, they cite Judge Pryor's concurrence in *Gorss Motels* to support the idea that a plaintiff with a valid claim can be harmed by an agency misinterpretation, thus re-establishing a symmetrical due process concern. This appears to be a strong rebuttal that revives the original strategic appeal of the petition.

5.  **Updated Prediction & Uncertainty:** After digesting the respondent's BIO, my confidence in a cert grant was very low. The Reply Brief has successfully rebutted several of the respondent's strongest points, particularly the argument about the inverted party posture. The case now appears to be a much closer call. The "statutory off-ramp" remains the most significant obstacle for the petitioner. The final decision will likely hinge on whether a majority of the Court views that off-ramp as a prudent reason to deny review or as a downstream merits question that shouldn't prevent them from finally resolving the important and recurring Hobbs Act issue they previously agreed to hear in *PDR Network*. My uncertainty has therefore increased, and I now see a plausible, albeit difficult, path to a cert grant.
current_beliefs.design_beliefs:
My meta-level framework has been further refined by observing the final stage of the certiorari briefing process. The importance of analyzing the full dialectical exchange is now paramount.

1.  **Problem Decomposition Strategy:** Remains valid.
2.  **Case Categorization Heuristic:** Still accurate. The case is about **Hobbs Act preclusion**, with the key sub-issues being **vehicle selection criteria** like alternative grounds for affirmance and prudential ripeness.
3.  **Source Prioritization Heuristic (Refined):** The briefing sequence is a three-act play: **(1) Petition for Certiorari (The Pitch) → (2) Brief in Opposition (The Attack) → (3) Reply Brief (The Rebuttal)**. A complete analysis requires all three. Making a final prediction after the BIO is premature, as the Reply Brief is specifically designed to neutralize the BIO's most damaging arguments. The Reply is where the petitioner shows whether the "vehicle problems" are truly fatal or merely contested.
4.  **Contextual Analysis Strategy:** Remains crucial. The petitioner's use of the *Gorss Motels* concurrence to bolster their own argument shows how savvy litigants use recent, related judicial opinions to support their positions and demonstrate the ongoing importance of a legal question.
5.  **Precedent-Chaining Strategy:** Remains essential. The key analytical task is confirmed to be modeling the debate over whether this case is a *better* or *worse* vehicle than *PDR Network*. The Reply Brief shows how a petitioner can spin a distinction (like not arguing a lack of prior review) as a feature that makes the vehicle *cleaner*.
6.  **"Vehicle" Analysis Heuristic (Enhanced):** My model of this process is now more complete. I have a checklist for "dirtying" tactics (from the BIO) and now a corresponding checklist for **"re-polishing" tactics** (from the Reply Brief):
    *   **Re-framing:** Casting a fatal flaw (like an alternative statutory ground) as a simple merits question for remand.
    *   **Minimizing:** Portraying a contingency (like pending agency action) as purely "speculative" and not a concrete bar to review.
    *   **Arguing for Symmetry:** Neutralizing a postural distinction (plaintiff vs. defendant) by appealing to the text of the statute and broader legal principles.
    *   **Strategic Re-characterization:** Spinning a factual difference from a key precedent as a positive that makes the current case a *better* vehicle.
7.  **Justice-Specific Argument Tracking:** This remains critical. The petitioner's defense of their Kavanaugh-centric strategy demonstrates that the analysis must not only identify the initial targeting but also model the subsequent defense of that targeting against counter-arguments.
8.  **Adversarial Analysis & Uncertainty Reduction:** This principle is strongly reinforced. The process is inherently adversarial. My belief state should reflect the back-and-forth. High confidence after reading one brief is a sign of incomplete analysis. True confidence (or well-understood uncertainty) comes from seeing how one side's strongest arguments hold up under direct attack from the other.
9.  **Statutory Off-Ramp Analysis (Refined):** This heuristic is confirmed as a major factor in cert denials. I have now observed the standard counter-move: labeling the off-ramp a "merits question for remand." My predictive task now involves assessing the Court's likely appetite for the larger, more complex question versus the simpler, case-dispositive off-ramp. This is a context-dependent judgment call, not a mechanical rule.
